subject: Re: [junit] Programming By Contract
msgSnippet: ... And that is the argument for having assertion failures be Error rather than RuntimeException. Imagine what happens when somebody litters the code with
messageBody:
--- John Brewer <jbrewer@...> wrote:

>An Error is a subclass of Throwable that indicates serious problems
>that a reasonable application should not try to catch.

And that is the argument for having assertion failures be Error rather
than RuntimeException. Imagine what happens when somebody litters the
code with "catch (RuntimeException e)" because there are a whole lot of
unchecked exceptions floating around. Having assertions failures be
Error means that only the most crude and brutish programmers (who
"catch (Throwable e)" or "catch (Error e)") will get it. Frankly, those
heathens deserve what they get.

Assertion failures should be caught. Meyer is right on this.

Regards,

Rob
